div.head: General Considerations and Overview
div.p: This chapter describes the TEI encoding mechanisms available for genres of computer-mediated communication (CMC) and thus social media. It is intended to provide the basic framework needed to encode CMC corpora.

While the term “computer-mediated communication” might be used to describe all sorts of communications between humans in the modern age (for example, internet video meetings or cellular telephony), herein we use the term to apply to the more traditional forms of computer-mediated asynchronous communication like text messages, instant messaging, email, chat rooms, online forums, social network services.

The salient feature of these CMC mediums is that a communicative act is generated, typically at the author’s leisure, in the private space of the author, and then transmitted en bloc to the recipient(s). Even though in some CMC genres (e.g., WhatsApp), the other parties are informed by an automated alert about the fact that another party is currently composing a new post, they cannot track the process of verbalization, i.e. how the written utterance emerges in the entry form on the user interface of its author. It is not until the author performs a ‘posting’ action (for example, by hitting the ‘enter’ key or by activating a ‘send’ button with the mouse) that the result of the composition process — the post — is made available for the other parties. From the perspective of its addressees or readers, a post is a stretch of text that has been composed in advance. Different from spoken utterances but similar to edited text, (1) the reader of a post does not have access to the verbalization process and (2) the mental processing of a post is not possible until the process of verbalization (the composition) has been finished and the posting action has been performed by the author. Posts occur in a broad range of written CMC genres, including (but not limited to): as user ‘messages’ in chats and WhatsApp dialogues, as SMS messages, as tweets in Twitter timelines, as individual comments following a status update on Facebook pages, as posts in forum threads, as contributions on Wikipedia talk pages, and in the comments section of a weblog.

div.head: Documenting CMC (and providing general meta data)
CMC Posts
div.p: The element post characterizes computer-mediated communication (CMC). A post is defined as a written (sometimes spoken) contribution to an ongoing CMC interaction which (1) has been composed by its author in its entirety as part of a private activity, and (2) has been sent to the server en bloc. It may co-occur with u, kinesic, incident, or other existing TEI elements within a div, or directly within the body, and may contain headings, paragraphs, openers, closers, or salutations.

As a member of the TEI attribute classes att.ascribed, att.canonical, att.datable, att.global, att.timed, and att.typed, posts may take a variety of attributes. Common attributes used in conjunction with post include who, synch, type, subtype, rend, and xml:id.

div.head: Attributes specific to CMC post
div.p:
Three attributes pertain specifically to post:
The modality attribute is required on the post element in order to describe the creation mechanism used in the CMC environment. The type of the content (i.e., whether the content of the post is written, an image, a video clip, etc.) is indicated by the child elements of the post. For example a written post from WhatsApp might include an audio-visual clip copied into the post, and in such case may not actually have any writing. Such a post is still considered in the “written” modality.
Screenshot von der Google-Suche nach dem Friseur "Haarraum" mit der Durchschnitts-Google-Bewertung (4,5 von 5 Sternen), der Adresse, der Telefonnummer und den Öffnungszeiten

The replyTo attribute is used to capture information drawn from the original metadata associated with a post that asserts to which previous post the current post is a response, or to which previous post it refers. This metadata is included by many, but not all, CMC environments, when the user executes a formal reply action (e.g., by clicking or tapping a reply button). This attribute should not be used to encode interpreted or inferred reply relations based on linguistic cues or discourse markers.

The replyTo attribute indicates the replied-to or referred-to posts by providing one or more pointers to them. For example:
Es hat den Anschein, als wäre bei BER durchaus große Kompetenz am Bau, allerdings nicht in Form von Handwerkern….
http://www.zeit.de/2015/29/imtech-flughafen-berlin-ber-verzoegerung/komplettansicht
Nein Nein, an den Handwerkern kann es rein strukturel nicht gelegen haben. Niemand lässt seine Handwerker auf der Baustelle derart allein. Zudem gibt es höchstoffizielle “Abnahmen” von Bauabschnitten/phasen. Welcher Mangel auch bestanden hatte, er hätte Zeitnah auffallen müssen.
Uuups, für Imtek hab ich mal in einer Nachunternehmerfirma gearbeitet. Imtek is offenbar ein universeler Bauträger, der alles baut.
Stahlkunstruktionen dacht ich mal, was die bauen – oder bauen lassen.
Das ist schon ein übles Ding. Die Ausschreibungenund Angebote sind unauffällig, aber wenn Unregelmässigkeiten auftreten (im Bauverlauf) dann gibt es die saftigen Rechnungen. Da steht dann der Bauherr da und fragt sich, wie er denn so schnell einen fähigen Ersatz herbekommt. Und diese Frage erübrigt sich meist, weil der Markt der Baufirmen das nicht hergibt – weil tendenziel 100 % Auslastung. (und noch schlimmer: Absprachen) Was auch Folge des Marktdrucks gewesen war.
Example: Three blog comments where, by the reply references in the source, the first is a reply to the initial blog post (not part of the example), the second is a reply to the first, and the third is a reply to the second.

In the CMC genre of Wiki talk, users insert their contribution to a discussion by modifying the wiki page of the discussion — the talk page. Since there is no technical reply action available in wiki software, users apply textual indentation in the wiki code to indicate a reply to a previous message, and a threaded structure is formed by a series of such indentations. The attribute indentLevel records the level of indentation, that is the nesting depth of the current post in such a thread-like structure (as defined by its author and in relation to the standard level of non-indentation which is to be encoded as indentLevel="0"). It is used in wiki talk corpora but may also be used for other threaded genres e.g. when HTML was used as a source.

div.head: Emojis and Emoticons
div.p: Emojis and emoticons are interaction signs represented by pictograms or icons such as smileys used abundantly in CMC.

Emoticons predate emojis and are typed on a keyboard using a combination of ASCII punctuation and other characters such as “;-)”, and occurred in newsgroup and chat communication as early as the mid-1980s.

Emojis are more recent interaction signs that are encoded as Unicode characters and offered in CMC environments as small icon graphics such as . An emoji is typically a single Unicode character which is intended to be mapped directly to a pictorial symbol. An emoticon is typically several Unicode characters (from the subset known as ASCII) in a row, each of which has an intended use other than as part of an emoticon.

Either emoticons or emojis may be simply transcribed as a sequence of characters. As with any other characters, they may be entered as numeric character entities if this is more convenient. (E.g., “😷” might be transcribed as “😷” in any XML document, including a TEI document; see .)

When the text of a post is being tokenized, e.g. for linguistic analysis, it may be useful to encode the emoticon or emoji as a separate token. In such cases elements like w and pc may be used for tokenization, and the pos attribute may be used to indicate that the encoded string is an emoji or an emoticon. (See .)

Alternatively, e.g. when w is not regularly used to encode tokens in the TEI document, c can be used to mark an emoji. For example, the source post “Da kostet ein Haarschnitt 50 € 😱” might be encoded as follows:

Sometimes, e.g. when the source of the TEI document was a web page in HTML, the emojis may occur only as an icon graphic in the source. In that case, they can be encoded in TEI using figure. The corresponding unicode character can then be recorded in the desc element by the encoder if desired.

div.head: Post with graphics
div.p: A post in a CMC interaction may contain a graphic in addition to some text or even contain only a graphic (without any text). As explained in [REF section on @modality], the modality of such a post should be considered as “written”. To encode the graphic information, the TEI element figure should be used in the appropriate place.

div.p: Example: Encoding of a tweet that contains some text (including hashtags and mentions) and a graphic. The graphic element retains the url of the graphic on the web just as in the source.

div.head: “Putting it all together” – genre specific examples
The TEI CMC Module
div.p:
The module described in this chapter makes available the following components:
Elements, Attributes, and Models for Computer-mediated communication (CMC). This module collects all cmc-specific extensions. Hence these will only be added to a TEI schema when this module is selected in a customisation. TEI-CMC Computer-Mediated Communication The selection and combination of modules to form a TEI schema is described in .
